comment: Slight smoke, bit of berry, oak, sherry. Fine, but not terribly exciting
Not too peaty and smooth drink, enjoyed it with a friend and a cigar
Pretty good! I remember feeling a cinnamon after taste though I don’t think it was made with any.
this is the one you ordered at Jack Rose when Max Phillips was in town
Sweet and fruity. Quite balanced and light. Spicy throughout. Not very long lasting aftertaste.

A swirl of aromas. Sweet and candy sour. Sour apple and occasional whiffs of chocolate. Good body on this light colored spirit. Slight hint of peat within the dram but not enough to call this "peaty". This 10 year is smoother and more balanced then many older single malts.
sample/excellent whiskey, strong peat but not overwhelming
Tried this first in Scotland and it came in 2nd out of five in a group tasting. Highly drinkable, well-balanced, deliciously spicy and sweet.
Subtle smoke; sweet and rich; light peat. A little bite, but still smooth.

Long overdue review of this one---courtesy of my friend Lee, who provided a sample as part of Round 1 in our little Scotland distillery sampling.   Jura is a strange little distillery.  Sort of like that weird uncle we all have.  ( we all have one of those  uncles...if you don't, you're probably that uncle...;-) .  Strange in the sense that I find Jura all over the place, without a real identity.  I'm not sure it knows what it wants to be when it grows up.  I found this 10 yr old not unpleasant ( yes, double negative...), almost an inviting nose and taste.  But, the finish...my god, it's like having a piece of that white portion on lemons.  Bitter.  If you had $55 to spend, this might not be the smart buy.  Might want to look elsewhere.  It's decent...but, can do much better elsewhere at this price point.
Good.   Not nearly as peaty as I would have thought.
Not to fruity, a little harsh and has a bite. Overall pretty decent.
Adventskalender 2017: sehr gut, eher mild mit einem leichten Beigeschmack von Schinken
At lunch on bus trip. Mild smoke. Smooth.

4.0
Nose. Light peat
Palette. Light peat
Pleasant and mild. Great house single malt
Salty and a bit smoky and spicy.
Fruity smell that finishes a bit spicy. Very good
Average whisky. Mild peat, slightly oily, clean finish
Ridiculously smooth. Hint of sherry sweet
Light Vanilla, a hint of Apple-Pear fruit, touch of cinnamon, a nice amount of smoke that is very present but it overpowering.
nose: peat, wee fruit, taste: PEAT
good not great. very light peat, a bit of salt and some sherry. not enough smoke or sherry for my taste
A little Smoky with a sweet finish. Smooth with hardly a burn.
Smoke, honey and fruit. Quite good.
Smooth with minimal heat and a touch of peat
Smooth. Bit of smoke. Really nice for the price.

35ml pour. Toffee & dark fruit aroma. Full bodied, caramel toffee with some brine. Very light smoke.
Very pleasant and simple. Nomzzz.

Nose: Slightly smokey, lightly floral, sea air, sweet.

Taste: Minimal peat, charred wood, vanilla, slight almond.
Similar to Macallan 12 with a little peat
Pancakes. Chocolate blueberry pancakes, slightly over-cooked. Bad for a pancake, great for a whisky

Surprised how much I like it tonight. Citrus and smoke (and maybe iodine) on the nose, similar palette. Not too sweet, a little salty. The finish has a menthol bite that doesn’t last too long. Very pleasant sensations
Chocolate, honey, and raspberry syrup on the nose. Vanilla, ginger on the palate with a mild peat finish and smooth oily texture.

Nose: sweet candied peach / peach rings. Plums. Malty pancake. Semisweet chocolate. Plums. Oak. 

Taste: very light peat. Raisin. Bitter oak. Pancake maltiness. Plums. Very tart lime. Really dense sea salt. Parsley. Cilantro. Basil. Red apple, brown sugar / butterscotch. Peach rings.

Major league impressive. Tons of character at only 40%. Adding water takes all the subtleties away but intensifies the finish. I can see how people would dislike it though. Lots of intense bitter and sour flavors but really wonderful.
Nose: fruity, sweet, orange/vanilla. Taste: moderate spicy, sweet, long finish that show up a bit of peated but a bit loss in the sweetness, overall really pleasant
Sweet and easy to drink. Very light smoke. Finish similar to a Speyside. Think Glenmorangie. Great dram for the money. Not overly complex, but delicious.

typical scotch
too light, no complexity, too light.
nice, well balanced, a bit smoked
Not bad but I'm getting zero peat

Not what I want in a scotch.  Does not taste like ten years.  It’s light, heather and orange marmalade.  No burn, no peat.  Fruity but not particularly interesting.  I wanted to love this but it’s not my thing.

Very mighty alcohool smell and barely nothing else. It is possible to find some reminesence of peat.
At the mouth the dram shows his young age and his impetuosity with an unexperienced sensation of weight and heaviness crushing the tongue.
Did not enjoy it though because only a bit of salt and very light creamy aspect could overpass the strong alchohol taste
Pretty happy with this. Found it at a bar in the middle of nowhere. Even keeled flavor
Very interesting whiskey. One of the first island whiskeys for me. Odd fruity and honeyed nose.

Much better than I expected given the general negativity I hear about this distillery. Sweet but not cloying, decent amount of spice and caramel notes and a good length on the finish. Bodes well for the evening's Jura vertical.

The nose is great. A slight pungent peat smell with oranges and vanilla cream in the back ground. 

The pallete is where this comes alive. Its creamy candied fruits which fades quickly into a salty dry finish with just a slight smokiness. I would call the finish an average length which leaves you wanting more. 

For only a 10 year old scotch I feel like this great dram for the money and one that I enjoy taking my time with.

Over-ripe orchard fruit, honey and earthy swamp (bog?) on the nose. Unique but a bit off-putting. Immediate orchard fruit on the arrival which leaves the party far too soon. Astringent and bitter tea through the middle and finish, with the peat bog becoming the singular event. Good warmth throughout for 40%, but only add a drop of water. Moderately oily mouth-feel. Not my cup of tea.
Excelent balance of peat and fruity
Much spicier with a lightly harsher finish
Highly drinkable, pretty even flavored. Not a strong alcohol taste. A beer of whiskeys if you will
not picking up much smoke, even a subtle amount
highly underrated IMO. this has some smokeyness but not overbearing.great flavors all around.

The Distiller description is right on the money. Kinda of a Lagavulin light but in very good flavorable way. Served up in a Glen Cairn at an Old Town Alexandria whisky bar, the Jura was a very nice pour
Really good. Nice mix of peaty and smokey without being too much. Really smooth, easy finish.
Nice and sweet, slightly fruity too.
Cinnamon with honey predominates, a decent amount of spice (but wouldn’t hurt to have more), a touch of citrus.  The cinnamon lingers.

The nose: barrel bitterness,dried citrus fruit

The pallete: mildly spicy, orange, caramel, dry

The finish: short, barrel spice, faint bitter dark chocolate

Overall, not extremely complex, easy drinker for someone who doesnt like sweet scotches.

Great.
Nose was full of butterscotch. Taste was fruity, finishing with some smoke.
Peaty and sweet with a nice finish.  Would be a good starting place if you’re new to peated scotch.
like cheap HP12. Really good, ounches way above its price.
zoet en turf door elkaar. van voor in de mond zacht en tegen de zijkant van de tong en vanachter in de keel wat scherper. prettig dessertje wat mij betreft

Representing isle of Jura

Nose: syrupy sweetness like caramelized sherry. Oak. Sherry dominates with a hint of peat. Sugary. 

Body: thin

Palate: smooth, sweet, sherry dry raisin. Light peat, light oak

Finish: short light sweetness and peat and light smoke. 

Note: super easy, sugar bomb. The faint follow up smoke makes me feel like this is a good warm up to a springbank 15
Amaretto with a light spice, fading into  caramel and a hint of peat smoke

Interesting nose of dried fruit with a touch of smoke. Palate has wafts of smoke that come and go with dried fruit and light baking spices. Pretty simple but really enjoy the light smokiness that seems to come and go in waves.

On the nose it's litteraly smoked caramelized apple with sea salt on a musty leather chair.
On the palate it's pretty much the same but the apple is more apparent and there's some graham crackers ass well.
Finish is short with some sugar and some apple.
Decent whisky
Decent nose, various flavors. Nothing overly strong but a good balance. Great finish with a hint of chocolate

Some smoke on the nose, with a lot of malt, maybe some lemon?  I can definitely smell the sherry.

The palate has malt and a pleasant amount of smoke.  I can taste the sherry.  It's got a bit of pepper, more white pepper than black, and brine.

The body is light, but not in a bad way, it carries the coastal flavors nicely.

There is a decent amount going on here- the balance is not perfect, but there is a lot to like - it's got a lingering, intense, salty finish, and that is just fine by me.  It's a good drink for a cool fall day.
For beginner of Pete flavored whisky
Sweet, fruity for sure. Not too spicy though.
Aromatic, a little sharp, not my favorite
Spicy notes, fruity smell. Good, warm after-taste. A hint of peat.
Very light smell.  Subtle and light taste, even undiluted.  Can taste the peat smoke.  Can be sipped easily, but is also uninspiring.

ose: Vanilla, rich brown sugar, a little dry, kind of some rye n borbon notes
Taste: a little dark dry fruit sweet and tannic. Maybe a little citric. A little bit peaty. Very complex and would need more time to fully comprehend.
Quite sweet due to the sherry cask finish. Easy to drink.
Very smooth with a nice flavor. Smoke hits you at the end. It’s not too Smokey but it is there.

Very thin with little body in the front followed by light peat and heavier smoke. The finish is mostly barrel with the tannins shining through. Not bad but probably will stay on the shelf for a while.
Tastes a bit chemically to me

Nose: Smoke. Peat. Grapes/berries.

Flavour: Still peat and smoke. The fruity(ish) flavour still continues. 

Finish: The finish is not the longest but has a pleasant, and fairly mild, lingering taste of smoke with it.

I have the new formulation at 80 pf. Still is quite oily with good coating in glass and mouthfeel despite proof. Poured neat, nose is salty smoke, dry oak,coffee bean and malty dough. Palate continues this ending up tasting like a soft pretzel laced with coffee beans cooked in a smoker fueled with seasoned oak then heavily salted. Not a lot of sweet notes, some good malt presence, maybe a shimmer of pineapple similar to HP12 but then its gone. Finish is long with more salty pretzel, malt, coffee grounds and wood with cigar leaf lingering. Its kind of in the Bowmore profile but still a bit different and for sure better. Its unique and quite good but not elite imo. Lap 10 and Ard 10 are better in same range but I wouldn't mind having this around......87/100...........bottle is great too, makes for an easy pour with the shape. Update: after several pours and bottle being opened this keeps improving. The smoke and malt have thickened up with the coffee influence really shining. I think this is right there with Highland Park . Flat out recommend to those who enjoy smoky scotch and coffee notes. Score increases to solid 90/100
Really smelled the smokiness and coffee up front. The fruit and ginger I tasted with some chocolate and coffee. Nice long finish I thought.

Neat in Glencairn at home.  Nose is tons of pear with some grains and mild brine.  Taste has some peat smoke notes, particularly on the back end, with apples, heather, and sea breeze coming in and out.  The sea breeze lingers for a while, with some grains mixing in.  Quite decent, though far from stellar.   11/18/19.
Tasted in Edinburgh. Very nice with a little smoke.
A good balance of a little bit of peat and fruit notes. Also vanilla on the nose.
Orange scent, then peat and sweet. Interesting combination...
Not super peated,but has a nice sweet-smoky balance - would go great with a cigar given the ashy undertones but sugary overtones.
Very pleasant aroma of citrus orange with slight spice on front mellowing to a soilly, peaty finish.
Mellow, but not underwhelming. It was a gift and I am enjoying it.  The finish is really nice - best part.

This reminds me of a good beach party, it smells of a beach bon fire and seashore, the palate is reminiscent of eating a smore made with a sherry flambeed marshmallow, and the smoke stays with you a long time.

This tasting for Jura 10 Year is another “impressions” review as it was a public tasting while at a work event. I’ve seen a bit of mistrust for this distillery due to inconsistent releases. What better way to provide an advantage to this questionable dram than by trying it for free and preceding it with Johnnie Walker Black?  This event had an odd spirits selection to be sure....

Jura 10 consists of a mixture of peated and unpeated whiskies which are matured in bourbon barrels and finished in ex-oloroso sherry butts. It’s colored, chill-filtered, and bottled at 40% ABV. 

On the nose, there’s lightly medicinal peat and smoke. Sweet fruits (berry-like), heather, and coffee grounds. The palate amplifies these and adds a bit of spice, sea breeze, leather, cacao notes, and velvety tannins. It has decent mouthfeel, but in no way compares to the richness or intensity of many of its Islay neighbors. “Decent” in this case means, “wow, that’s not as weak as I was expecting for 40% ABV” - it’d be nice to see this higher. Finish is sweet, smokey, and a carries a bit of spice. I feel like this dram has more in common (character and flavor-wise) with some drams from the Highlands than nearby Islay. 

I think a bottle of this used to be quite expensive/overpriced, on the order of $50-$60. It looks like that has come down a bit, and can now be found for around $40-$45 (who knows how long that will last as the tariff effect trickles in).  That puts it on par with Laphroaig 10, which is delicious and exquisite but also challenging. If you seek a less complex hybrid between Islay and the Highlands and want to try something new, perhaps seek this out if you can find it around the $40 mark and have tempered expectations. 

3.25 ~ Average
Smooth start and finish with flavor felt on the back of the tongue
A little fruity, but I was unable to get the peatiness on this one.   A little light for my taste.
Sweet, peaty, mild. Good first whiskey for someone to try smoky.
Peaty up front, sweet finish. A little heat at the tail end and on the exhale. Best scotch I’ve had to date. On sale for $50. Highly recommend for anyone looking to get into scotch.
Nice, real good sherry, nice smokey finish very vanillary

When dining at a local restaurant which we last visited before I started appreciating Whisky, I was happily surprised of their small, but qualitative whisky menu. Besides Talisker 10, Lagavulin 16 and Dalwhinnie 15, they also carried the Jura 10 - one I hadn’t tried before. 

The nose was pleasant, a bit fruity, but with a whiff of peat smoke. The taste was similar, perhaps a tad more fruits, with some slight coffee notes. Some sweet chocolate. The aftertaste lingers on for a decent while, with the sweet notes giving way for the smoky notes after a few moments. 

Not a very complex dram, but very approachable. I enjoyed it. 
The level of peat smoke is somewhat similar to the Talisker 10.
Very sweet little to no alcohol burn or smoke flavor very easy drink

Nose: Black and green tea.  Smoke, wet earth, cloves, lemon oil.  Flour, salt - Play-Doh comes to mind.  Sweet floral notes.  Leather, cocoa, dusty books.  Apples, ginger, 

Palate: Black tea, smoke, tannin, oak, brown sugar, vanilla, strawberries.  Mildly sweet.  Super buried ash notes.  Char.  Moss.  Slight brine.  Coffee grinds.  Finish begins with a pause - no pop of flavors here, likely due to the lower proof.  Mouthfeel is moderate.  Things slowly ramp up to reveal earth, vanilla, oak, smoke, mild peat, and Hershey's milk chocolate.  The earth, vanilla, and smoke hang out while orange oil and pine oil notes show up in the background.  Things slowly fade away.  Medium-long finish, though not a ton of evolution throughout.

Other notes: Under the weather today, so my senses of smell and taste aren't at the top of their game.  That being said, I like this.  It might be a little less intense and bold compared to my usual leanings (Ardbeg has ruined me for peated Scotch), there's still a subtle complexity going on here that isn't disinteresting.  Excited to see what I'm missing when I'm back in action 100%.
Very fruity. Sweetness hides the smoke, which only comes through late on and is fairly light. Fruitier than I would normally go for, but that's no bad thing in this case as it wears it well.
Slightly smoky, very fruity flavor.  But if water really opens this one up. Great taste for the price at which I found it.
Overall well rounded. But needs a bit of depth. Sweet with a taste of spicy at the end.

The first couple of times I sipped this bottle I was not a big fan, and I blame Jura Superstition for perhaps setting the bar of my expectations a bit too high.

This Jura 10 is a very decent dram, whose low abv doesn't do it justice. 

Nose: caramelized pears and peaches, bubble gum berries and of course a hint of smoke.

Palate:  Oilier than I recall from previous sips, and spicier as well, not just in the finish. There more you sip, the more prevalent the smoke becomes, as well as the vanilla.

Finish: bitter cacao nibs, slight peppery spice and Peat smoke.

Sweet, fruity.
Nose: vanilla sweetness, citrus, sherry notes.
Palate: light sherry notes first, then spice.  Sweetness in the background. 
Finish: short, spice and oaky dryness.
The notes are blended well for its price bit it's something you can enjoy with a good cigar
So smooth! The peat is so tame on the taste and the sweetness really pops. Floral, vanilla and brine everywhere
Rich, smooth, fruit-cake, small amount of smoke, medium finish

Right off the bat the nose is molasses with a hint of butterscotch. The smoke is really just a puff but it does come through. Some black pepper that mingles with the inside of a sherry cask. Vanilla bean. There is a surprising chocolate and coffee base that comes at the tail end that I wasn't expecting. The nose is a lot more complex than I gave a credit for initially.

The first taste that I'm getting is those oloroso sherry casks: it's a sweet and rounded flavor but with just a hint of bitterness at the tail end.that flavor morphs into plums and stone fruits on the sides of the tongue. There is a tannic puckery flavor that comes through on the bottom of the tongue.The flavors are a combination of sweet and prickly spice. It is really a beautiful taste and one that I think you need to really sit with and ponder before you can truly appreciate it.

The finish is sweet cherry and sour sherry. The barrel aging comes through at just the right strength: It is not too overpowering but it is not weak either. Just a touch of tobacco and smoke at the very end. I am incredibly impressed with this scotch and I feel like I gave it short shrift on my first taste of it.

Olfato: maçãs vermelhas, baunilha, levemente turfado, caramelo, cítrico, notas de sherry, frutos vermelhos, dulçor e levemente acre. Nenhum álcool evidente.

Palato: muito dulçor, leve turfado, apimentado, amadeirado, cítrico (laranja), bom amargor, frutado (frutos vermelhos) e muito suave.

Finalização: médio para curto. Amargor permanece junto ao apimentado, realçado pela secura que segue nos segundos seguintes. 

Impressões gerais: whisky leve, pouco complexo e que possui várias características em uma única garrafa. As notas provenientes da maturação em barris de ex-bourbon e finalização em ex-sherry são perceptíveis, assim como as notas turfadas leves. Whisky com preço muito acessível, indicado para iniciantes e facilmente encontrado no mercado brasileiro.

A solid island single malt. Surprised I have not reviewed this one in the past. My review is for the 43% version. Noses of honey-malt, oak, and a hint of brine. These come across on the tongue, and now a touch of smoke and an oily mouthfeel. Heat and an astringency show up in the finish.
Mild peat aroma with a bit of cherry and oak. Smooth, soft texture, with a slightly peaty bitter aftertaste. Not overly sweet or spicy.

Upfront this whisky is like a smoky spicy sherry.  The first hit is spiced raisins, vanilla and chocolate.  It slowly develops into a sweet, smoky dram with a long finish.

Overall, it is a little harsh and the smokiness is a little jarring with the spicy, smoky finish.  It’s pretty drinkable, but there are better whiskies at the price point.  Possibly one for people used to a Speyside sherry-bomb who want to experiment with some of the strong Islay flavours, but with something a little more familiar to them.
